name: anthracene, 9-nitro-
Reason: 9-Nitroanthracene has a melting point that is influenced by several functional groups. The basic unit for comparison is anthracene, which has a melting point of 100°C. The nitro group introduces a strong withdrawing group, increasing intermolecular forces and melting point by approximately +50°C. The nitro group also introduces a dipole, increasing intermolecular forces and melting point by approximately +10°C. The additional functional groups and structural features in 9-nitroanthracene will affect its melting point: (1) Two phenyl groups, which could each add approximately +20 due to the increase in molecular weight and rigidity of the structure; (2) The tertiary butyl group (C(C)C) is a bulky group which could add about +10 due to steric hindrance and increasing the molecular volume; (3) The piperidine ring (N1CCCC1) and 1-ethyl-4-methylenepiperidine moiety may both add roughly +20 each due to adding more rigid ring structures and making the molecule more compact; (4) The nitro group introduces a strong withdrawing group, increasing intermolecular forces and melting point by approximately +50°C. Summing these modifications gives us an estimated melting point shift.
